description: From Middle English [Term?], from Old English eallmǣst (“nearly all, almost, for the most part”), equivalent to al- (“all”) +‎ most.

entries.meaning: Very close to, but not quite.
examples: Almost all people went there. (not all but very close to it)
We almost missed the train. (not missed but very close to it)

definitionGroups.group: (mathematics) Up to, except for a negligible set (where negligible is not universally but contextually defined).

entries.meaning: (measure theory, probability theory) Up to a null set; except for a set of measure 0.
(informal) Something or someone that doesn't quite make it.
examples: In all the submissions, they found four papers that were clearly worth publishing and another dozen almosts.
